questions.text: A 55 year old woman undergoes a cholecystectomy, after which she develops jaundice and abdominal pain. Imaging reveals a bile duct stricture at the confluence of the right and left hepatic ducts, but the ducts themselves are intact. According to the Bismuth classification, what type of stricture does she have?
questions.explanation:
Bismuth classification for biliary strictures

Type I
  • Common hepatic duct stump >2cm
  • Stricture is Low (Option A ruled out)

Type II
  • Common hepatic duct stump <2cm
  • Stricture is mid (Option B ruled out)

Type III
  • Hilar stricture with intact confluence
  • Stricture is high

Type IV
  • Hilar stricture with destroyed confluence (Option D ruled out)

Type V
  • Stricture involving aberrant right sectoral duct with or without stricture of common hepatic duct

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with worsening abdominal pain, jaundice, and fever. Ultrasound shows a choledochal cyst and bile duct obstruction. What imaging study is most appropriate for the next step in management?
questions.explanation:
INVESTIGATIONS - CHOLEDOCHAL CYST

Ultrasound
  • The first imaging test that is performed.
  • Confirms the presence of the cyst.
  • Reveals anatomical details, including bile duct and pancreatic duct relationship.

Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)
  • Non-invasive imaging technique. (Option B ruled out)
  • Provides detailed images of the gallbladder and biliary system.
  • Highly sensitive (>90%) and specific (>99%) for identifying common bile duct stones.
  • Visualizes biliary anatomy and the extent of dilatation.

Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP):
  • Invasive procedure with endoscope and contrast material.
  • Diagnostic and therapeutic capabilities (tissue sampling, decompression, treatment of choledocholithiasis).
  • Effective but has a complication rate of up to 10%.

Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography (PTC)
  • Invasive procedure with a needle directly into the liver.
  • Useful for intrahepatic biliary disease or when ERCP is not feasible. (Option D ruled out)
  • Helps delineate surgical anatomy and enables drainage catheter and stent placement.

CT SCAN

Mainly to see the intrahepatic biliary system (Option A ruled out)

Other Tests
  • Hepatobiliary nuclide Scanning
  • Liver Function Tests

questions.explanation:
Todani modification of Alonso- Lej classification

Type I

Ia

Cystic dilation of the extrahepatic bile duct (Most common)

Ib

Focal segmental dilation of extrahepatic bile duct

Ic

Fusiform dilation of extrahepatic bile duct

Type II

Diverticular dilation of extrahepatic bile duct

Type III

Dilatation of intraduodenal part of bile duct (choledochocele)

Type IV

IV a

Dilatation of both intra and extrahepatic bile duct
 

IV b

Multiple cysts involving extrahepatic bile duct only

Type V

Multiple cysts involving intrahepatic bile duct only (Caroli’s disease)

Type

Treatment

Type I

Complete excision, cholecystectomy, Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy

Type II

Complete excision

Type III

Transduodenal excision or sphincteroplasty (Option B ruled out); endoscopic drainage may suffice

Type IVa

Tailored to anatomy: extrahepatic cysts treated like Type I; partial hepatectomy and reconstruction for localized intrahepatic involvement (Option D ruled out)

Type IVb

Managed like Type I

Type V (Caroli disease)

Resection for unilobar disease; liver transplantation for diffuse disease (Option A ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma?
Which of the following is the classical triad of acute cholangitis?
questions.explanation:
Cholangitis

Aetiology

Often due to obstruction in the biliary tree, leading to bacterial infection by organisms like Klebsiella, E. coli, Enterobacter, Pseudomonas, and Citrobacter species.

Symptoms
  • Charcot's triad - pain, jaundice, fever
  • Additional tenderness in the epigastrium and right hypochondrium is common.
  • Severe Form: Reynolds pentad - persistent pain, fever, jaundice, shock, and altered mental status
  • Indicates acute obstructive suppurative cholangitis.

Lab Findings
  • Elevated white blood cell count, bilirubin, and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Chronic cases may show lobar or segmental atrophy or hypertrophy.

Recurrent Pyogenic Cholangitis
  • More common in East Asian populations, caused by intrahepatic stones and infections
  • Risk factors include parasitic infections like Clonorchis sinensis and Ascaris lumbricoides.

questions.text: A 40 year old patient is experiencing persistent abdominal pain and elevated serum amylase after undergoing ERCP. The pain began shortly after the procedure. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?

A 55 year old male with history of obesity and a low-protein diet presents with intermittent abdominal pain, jaundice, and recurrent episodes of dark urine and light-colored stools. Recently, he developed a fever with chills. Blood tests show elevated WBC count and abnormal liver function tests. MRCP reveals multiple pigmented stones in the common bile duct and intrahepatic ducts. What is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.explanation:
Primary CBD stone

Secondary CBD stone
  • Formed inside the common bile duct
  • The most common stone is the brown stone.
  • More common in developing countries due to worm infestations such as Ascaris and Clonorchis sinensis.
  • Formed in the gall bladder which slips into the common bile duct.
  • The most common type: is cholesterol stone
  • More common in developed countries

Symptoms

Features

Pain
  • Biliary colic to non-specific abdominal pain.
  • Biliary colic is a sudden, severe, colicky pain in the right upper quadrant that radiates to the back and shoulder.
  • It is precipitated by a fatty or heavy meal and can last for a few hours.
  • The pain is typically located in the ep igastrium and right hypochondrium.

Jaundice
  • Jaundice, a yellowing of the skin and eyes, is the most common clinical manifestation of choledocholithiasis.
  • It occurs due to the obstruction of bile flow, leading to the accumulation of bilirubin in the blood.
  • The jaundice associated with choledocholithiasis is likely to be painful because the onset of obstruction is often acute.

Fever
  • The presence of fever with chills and rigors is suggestive of cholangitis, a serious complication of choledocholithiasis.
  • Cholangitis occurs when the obstruction of the bile duct leads to bacterial infection and inflammation.
  • Charcot’s triad : Pain + Fever + Jaundice
  • Reynauld’s pentad: Mental status changes + Hypotension + Charcot’s triad

Changes in urine and stool
  • Obstruction of the bile duct can lead to darkening of the urine and lightening of the stools.
  • Steatorrhea, or fatty stools, may occur due to the impaired absorption of fat and fat-soluble vitamins caused by the lack of bile in the intestines.

Other symptoms

Pruritus (itching), loss of appetite, weight loss, nausea, and vomiting.

Laboratory tests reveal elevated serum ALP and gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGTP). MRCP shows stricturing and beading of the bile ducts. What is the most likely diagnosis?

An ultrasound shows multiple stones and a severely dilated common bile duct. What is the next best step in management?

A 62 year old male presents with jaundice and severe abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant that started abruptly after a heavy meal. He also reports dark urine, pale stools, and intermittent fever with chills. An ultrasound shows a dilated common bile duct. ERCP is planned for stone removal. What is the maximum size of the stone that can typically be removed by ERCP without additional procedures?
questions.explanation:
Choledocholithiasis

Investigation
  • Ultrasound: Useful for detecting gallstones and CBD dilation but has limited sensitivity for CBD stones
  • MRCP: Non-invasive, excellent for visualizing biliary tree anatomy and pathology.
  • ERCP: Highly sensitive, both diagnostic and therapeutic for CBD stones.
  • PTC: Used when ERCP is not feasible, such as post-gastrectomy patients or unsuccessful ERCP attempts.
  • EUS: Invasive but accurate for diagnosing choledocholithiasis.
  • Blood Tests: ↑ bilirubin, ↑alkaline phosphatase, and ↑white blood cell count indicate choledocholithiasis and possible complications like cholangitis.

Treatment
  • Endoscopic Management: ERCP with sphincterotomy and stone extraction; stenting if necessary.
  • Percutaneous Removal: Used when endoscopic access is difficult.
  • Surgery: Options include laparoscopic and open choledocholithotomy, choledochoduodenostomy, and choledochojejunostomy.

Complications
  • Cholangitis: Bacterial infection due to obstructed bile flow, leading to fever, chills, right upper quadrant pain, and jaundice.
  • Pancreatitis: Inflammation of the pancreas due to obstruction at the ampulla of Vater.
  • Liver Damage: Prolonged obstruction can cause biliary cirrhosis and liver failure.
  • Biliary Stricture: Chronic inflammation can lead to the narrowing of the bile ducts.
  • Gallstone Ileus: Large gallstone eroding into the intestine, causing mechanical obstruction.
